tutorial.title: Pixel Grid - Part 2
tutorial.descriptionContent: In the second part, you'll set up the front-ent to consume the API and display the grid that the back-end returns

executableContent.instructions:
Welcome to the front-end part of the **Pixel Grid** project. In this first front-end part, we'll consume the API and display the grid that the back-end returns.

We'll start by creating a `PixelGrid` component to display the grid.

1. In the `PixelGrid.jsx` file, create a new React component called `PixelGrid` that accepts properties. Ensure that you import `React` and export the component as well.
2. Return a `div` element with the `className` set to `"grid"`.
3. Inside the `div` loop over the passed property `grid`, which will be the array that the database returns.
   - Display a `div` for every item in the passed array `grid`.
   - Every rendered item should have the `className` set to `"gridItem"`.
4. In the `App.jsx` file, import the `PixelGrid` component and display it. When rendering it, pass it an array with a few elements as the `grid` property.

files.name: index.html
files.content: loading

files.name: index.jsx
App.jsx
PixelGrid.jsx

executableContent.instructions:
Let's style the pixels to make them visible.

1. Import the `PixelGrid.css` file in the `PixelGrid.jsx` file.
2. Switch to the `PixelGrid.css` file to style the `.grid` class to display a grid of 20 times 20 elements of 20px times 20px:
   - Set `display` to `grid`.
   - Set `grid-template-columns` to `repeat(20, 20px)`.
   - Set `grid-template-rows` to `repeat(20, 20px)`.
3. Add another rule to target the `.gridItem` class:
   - Set `width` to `20px`.
   - Set `height` to `20px`.
   - Set `border` to `1px solid lightgray`.

executableContent.instructions:
Let's make the magic happen by connecting the front-end to the back-end. First, we'll need to fetch the data so our app can display it. For now, those are just white pixels. But hey, we already load them from our back-end!

During the guided project, you can use `process.env.BACKEND_URL` as the back-end. This back-end runs for the time while you work on the guided project. Afterward, you can continue building by using the publicly available URL from your own server on Mimo.

1. In `App.jsx`, import `useEffect` and `useState` from React.
2. Create a state variable named `grid` using `useState` and initialize it as an empty array.
3. Use `useEffect` to make a GET request to the `"/grid"` endpoint of the back-end. Set the result to the `grid` state variable.
4. In case of an error, catch it and log it to the console.
5. Pass the state variable `grid` to the `PixelGrid` component instead of the previously defined array. If you do that, you should see the 20 times 20 grid.

executableContent.instructions:
Since we now have the full 400 pixels to display, let's add more styling to optimize the grid for mobile devices.

1. In the `PixelGrid.css` file, add a media query to target files with a maximum width of 440px.
2. Target the `.grid` class inside the media query:
   - Set `grid-template-columns` to `repeat(20, 4vw)`.
   - Set `grid-template-rows` to `repeat(20, 4vw)`.
3. Add another rule to target the `.gridItem` class inside the media query:
   - Set `width` to `4vw`.
   - Set `height` to `4vw`.

executableContent.instructions:
Let's update our `PixelGrid` component to render each grid cell item with its respective color. Every pixel will still be white as the back-end initiated every pixel with a white color. We'll soon enable the front-end to change the color, too!

1. In the `PixelGrid` component, when iterating over the passed `grid` property, set the `key` and add a `style` property.
   - Set the `key` property to something unique, like the index or a combination of the x and y values of the item.
   - Set the `backgroundColor` to the `color` property of the item.
   - Set the `gridColumnStart` to the `x` value `+ 1` of the item.
   - Set the `gridRowStart` to the `y` value `+ 1` of the item.

executableContent.instructions:
Lastly, we want to add some general CSS styles to make the app visually appealing.

1. Import the `App.css` file in the `App.jsx` file.
2. Ensure the top-level element that the `App` component renders is a `div` with the class `"content-wrapper"`, which holds the `PixlGrid` component.
2. Switch to the `App.css` file to create a rule that targets `html`, `body`, and  the`.content-wrapper` class:
   - Set `height` to `100%`.
   - Set `display` to `flex`.
   - Set `flex-direction` to `column`.
   - Set `justify-content` to `center`.
   - Set `align-items` to `center`.
